questions.text: Which of the following factors does not indicate a favourable prognosis for schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Insidious onset of symptoms

  • In schizophrenia, an insidious onset is typically associated with a worse prognosis.
  • It often reflects a more chronic course of the illness, with poorer long-term outcomes, as the symptoms develop slowly over time and can be harder to treat effectively.

Prognostic factors of Schizophrenia

Positive factors

Negative factors
  • Acute onset
  • Female sex
  • Living in a developed country
  • Presence of mood symptoms (Option D ruled out)
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • Married

 
  • Insidious onset
  • Childhood or adolescent onset
  • Poor premorbid functioning
  • Cognitive impairment
  • Absence of mood symptoms
  • Negative symptoms
  • Family History of schizophrenia
  • Single/ separated/ divorced

 

Positive symptoms (Option A) of schizophrenia include hallucinations, delusions, and disorganised thinking. These symptoms usually tend to respond better to treatment, especially with antipsychotic medications. Positive symptoms are typically associated with a better prognosis compared to negative symptoms, which usually contribute to a bad prognosis.

Late age of onset (Option B) of schizophrenia occurs after age 45 years of age, and it usually correlates with a better prognosis, as it often involves less severe cognitive decline and better treatment responses.

questions.text: A man reports that he is receiving orders from God to follow white birds in a specific direction. What is the most appropriate description of this symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Delusional perception

Explanation:

  • Delusional perception occurs when a real, normal perception is given a false, fixed, and idiosyncratic meaning that is not culturally or logically justified.
  • It is a primary delusion, meaning it arises suddenly without preceding mental illness symptoms or logical explanation.
  • In this case, seeing white birds is real, but interpreting them as divine orders to follow is delusional perception.
  • Often seen in schizophrenia and other primary psychotic disorders.

Visual hallucination (Option B): Involves seeing things that are not present in reality; here the bird exists, but its meaning is delusional.

Thought insertion (Option C): Belief that external forces are putting thoughts into one’s mind, not misinterpretation of a real object.

Passivity phenomenon (Option D): Belief that one’s own actions, feelings, or impulses are being controlled by an outside force, not simply assigning false meaning to perception.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia, developed muscular dystonia and was treated for it. The patient now presents with complaints of dry mouth, dizziness, and hypotension. What is the most likely drug causing these side effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Benzotropine:

Explanation:

The patient with schizophrenia likely developed acute dystonia as a side effect of antipsychotic therapy, which is commonly treated with an anticholinergic drug like benztropine.

  • Treatment: Muscular dystonia is typically treated with anticholinergic medications. These drugs work by blocking acetylcholine activity to restore the balance of neurotransmitters in the brain.
  • New Symptoms: The patient now presents with dry mouth, dizziness, and hypotension. These are classic side effects of anticholinergic drugs.
    • Dry mouth: Caused by the anticholinergic effect of blocking muscarinic receptors in the salivary glands.
    • Dizziness and hypotension: Can be caused by the drug's effect on blood pressure regulation and the central nervous system.

Incorrect Options:

Risperidone (Option B): This is an atypical antipsychotic. While it can cause some EPS, it is more likely to be the drug that caused the dystonia, not the drug used to treat it.

Haloperidol (Option C): This is a potent typical antipsychotic. It is the type of drug that is a classic cause of muscular dystonia, not the treatment for it.

Propranolol (Option D): This is a beta-blocker. It is sometimes used to treat another type of EPS called akathisia, but it is not the primary treatment for dystonia, and its side effect profile does not typically include dry mouth.

questions.text: A girl with schizophrenia presents to a Primary Health Centre (PHC) in India. Which of the following online applications, provided by the Government of India (GOI), is used for mental health service support?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tele MANAS:

Explanation:

Tele MANAS, which stands for Tele Mental Health Assistance and Networking Across States, is the correct answer. It is a landmark initiative by the Government of India (GOI) to provide mental health services to the public.

  • Service Offerings: Tele-MANAS is a 24/7, toll-free tele-mental health service designed to provide immediate mental health support to individuals in distress.
  • Accessibility: It is available through a toll-free number (14416) and is part of the National Mental Health Programme. It aims to bridge the gap in mental health care by providing accessible services, particularly in remote and underserved areas.

Incorrect Options:

U-WIN (Option B) is an application developed by the government for immunization tracking, similar to the Co-WIN platform used for COVID-19 vaccination.

NIKUSHT (Option C) is a digital platform for the management and monitoring of sickle cell disease.

NIKSHAY (Option D) is the National Tuberculosis Information and Reporting System, used for TB control and management in India.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia says, "Hanuman ji is celibate. I am also celibate, so I am Hanuman." This statement is an example of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Autistic behaviour

Explanation:

  • The given statement is a example of Austictic behaviour, as it is a illogical thinking, based entirely on the patient's inner mental world, disconnected from external logic or reality
  • This is common in schizophrenia, where patients may draw bizarre and illogical conclusions that make sense only to them.
  • According to Eugen Bleuler, the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia include (4 ‘A’s):
    • Affect (emotional expression) disturbances : Patients often exhibit diminished emotional expression, which can be observed through a lack of facial expressions and emotional responsiveness.
    • Association (thought processes) disturbances: refers to disorganised thinking, where patients may form unusual or illogical connections in their thoughts, such as catastrophic beliefs about the world.
    • Autism (social withdrawal) refers to detachment from reality, evident in patients who may appear silent around others and frequently engage in self-directed conversation.
    • Ambivalence (mixed feelings): Patients experience conflicting emotions or attitudes, which can lead to indecisiveness and difficulty making choices.

Incorrect Options:

Neologism (Option A) is creation of entirely new, made-up words or ordinary words used in a new way, are often linked to schizophrenia.

  • Example: A patient says, "I need to go to the flibberflam store to get some boozleberries." These words are not real and have meaning only to the speaker.

Word salad (Option B) is incoherent, incomprehensible mixture of words and phrases, often seen in advanced schizophrenia.

﻿﻿﻿Loosening of association (Option D) involves shifting from one idea to another with weak connections, but here the thoughts are tightly focused on one theme.

questions.text: Which lobes may be impacted in a 40-year-old woman who has a history of urinating in public without feeling any remorse, along with difficulties in motivation and mild memory deficits?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C.

  • Frontal lobe: The frontal lobe plays a crucial role in executive functions, which include decision-making, motivation, impulse control, emotional regulation, and social behavior. Dysfunction or lesions in the frontal lobe can lead to changes in behavior, impulsivity, disinhibition, impaired judgment, and difficulties in motivation. The symptoms described in the scenario, such as urinating in public without remorse and difficulty in getting motivated, are more consistent with frontal lobe dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Parietal lobe: The parietal lobe is primarily involved in processing sensory information and spatial awareness. It plays a role in integrating sensory input, perception of touch, spatial orientation, and body awareness. However, the symptoms described in the scenario, such as urinating in public without remorse, difficulty in motivation, and mild memory deficits, are not typically associated with lesions or dysfunction in the parietal lobe.

Option B. Occipital lobe: The occipital lobe is primarily responsible for processing visual information. It is involved in visual perception, object recognition, and visual memory. However, the symptoms mentioned in the scenario do not directly align with occipital lobe dysfunction, as they are not primarily related to visual processing or visual disturbances.

Option D. Temporal lobe: The temporal lobe is involved in various functions, including memory, language processing, auditory perception, and emotional regulation. While mild memory deficits can be associated with temporal lobe dysfunction, the other symptoms described in the scenario, such as urinating in public without remorse and difficulty in motivation, are not commonly associated with isolated temporal lobe dysfunction

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered acute organic mental disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • Delirium is the most common acute organic mental disorder. It is an acute confusional state characterized by a disturbance in attention and awareness. Delirium often has a rapid onset and fluctuating course, and it is commonly caused by underlying medical conditions, such as infections, metabolic imbalances, drug intoxication, or withdrawal. Delirium is a medical emergency that requires prompt evaluation and treatment to address the underlying cause and manage the symptoms.

Incorrect option:

Option B. Dementia: Dementia is a chronic and progressive neurocognitive disorder characterized by a decline in memory, thinking, behavior, and the ability to perform daily activities. Unlike delirium, dementia develops slowly and gradually over time, and it is not considered an acute disorder. While dementia can cause cognitive impairment, it is not the most common acute organic mental disorder.

Option C. Amnesia: Amnesia refers to the loss of memory, either partial or complete, due to various causes such as brain injury, trauma, or psychological factors. While amnesia can occur acutely, it is not as common as delirium as an acute organic mental disorder. Delirium involves not only memory impairment but also disturbances in attention, awareness, and other cognitive functions.

Option D. Anxiety disorder: Anxiety disorder is a broad term that encompasses various mental health conditions characterized by excessive worry, fear, and anxiety. While anxiety disorders can occur acutely, they are not classified as acute organic mental disorders. Acute organic mental disorders typically refer to conditions with an acute onset and organic (physiological) etiology, such as delirium caused by medical factors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a negative symptom of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct option. A

  • Negative symptoms of schizophrenia are characterized by deficits or reductions in normal emotional, cognitive, or behavioral functioning. They reflect a loss or diminishment of typical functioning rather than an excess or overactivity. Therefore, "Over activity" is the correct answer as it is not considered a negative symptom of schizophrenia.

Incorrect option: 

Option B. Anhedonia: Anhedonia is a negative symptom of schizophrenia. It refers to the loss of interest or pleasure in previously enjoyable activities. Individuals with schizophrenia may have difficulty experiencing joy or finding satisfaction in things they used to find pleasurable.

Option C. Alogia: Alogia is a negative symptom of schizophrenia. It is characterized by reduced speech output or impoverished speech content. Individuals with alogia may have difficulty expressing themselves or providing detailed responses in conversations.

Option D. Apathy: Apathy is a negative symptom of schizophrenia. It refers to a lack of interest, motivation, or enthusiasm in activities or goals. Individuals with apathy may have reduced drive or find it difficult to initiate and sustain activities.

questions.text: Which one of the options does not contribute as a risk factor for delusional disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D. Young age.

  • Delusional disorder is a psychiatric condition characterized by the presence of persistent delusions without significant impairment in other cognitive functions. Delusions are fixed, false beliefs that are maintained despite evidence to the contrary. While various factors can contribute to the development of delusional disorder, young age is not considered a significant risk factor.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Recent immigration: Recent immigration can be a risk factor for delusional disorder. The stressors and challenges associated with adapting to a new environment, cultural differences, and social isolation can potentially contribute to the development of delusions.

Option B. Social isolation: Social isolation or lack of social support is considered a risk factor for delusional disorder. It can lead to feelings of loneliness, exacerbate existing delusions, and contribute to the persistence of abnormal beliefs.

Option C. Family history: Family history of psychiatric disorders, including delusional disorder, is considered a risk factor. There may be a genetic predisposition or shared environmental factors within families that contribute to the development of delusions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a core symptom of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option. B

  • Automatism: Automatism is not a fundamental symptom of schizophrenia. Automatism refers to automatic, involuntary movements or behaviors without conscious control or awareness. In the context of schizophrenia, the primary symptoms include positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions), negative symptoms (e.g., reduced emotional expression, social withdrawal), and cognitive impairments (e.g., disorganized thinking, difficulty concentrating). Automatism is not considered a core feature or defining symptom of schizophrenia.

Incorrect options 

Option A. Autism: Autism is a developmental disorder characterized by difficulties in social interaction, communication challenges, and repetitive behaviors. Autism and schizophrenia are separate diagnostic entities with distinct symptomatology. While some symptoms may overlap between autism and schizophrenia, they are considered distinct disorders with different underlying causes and diagnostic criteria.

Option C. Association defect: Association defect, also known as formal thought disorder or disorganized thinking, is a fundamental symptom of schizophrenia. It refers to disruptions in the logical and coherent flow of thoughts, resulting in difficulties in organizing and expressing ideas coherently. Association defects can manifest as tangential thinking, loose associations, or incoherent speech patterns.

Option D. Ambivalence: Ambivalence, or the coexistence of conflicting feelings or attitudes, can be present in schizophrenia but is not considered a fundamental symptom. Ambivalence can manifest as mixed emotions, contradictory thoughts, or indecisiveness. It is more commonly associated with other psychiatric conditions, such as borderline personality disorder, rather than being specific to schizophrenia.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a person experiencing a reduced sense of enjoyment in activities that they previously found pleasurable?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: Anhedonia

  • Anhedonia refers to the decreased ability to experience pleasure or a lack of interest in activities that were previously enjoyable. It is a symptom commonly associated with various mental health conditions, particularly depressive disorders such as major depressive disorder (MDD). Other symptoms of depression may also be present alongside anhedonia, such as changes in appetite, sleep disturbances, low mood, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating.
  • There are two types of anhedonia:
    1. Social anhedonia: This refers to a reduced ability to experience pleasure from social interactions or relationships. People with social anhedonia may find it difficult to engage in and enjoy social activities, leading to feelings of isolation and disconnection.
    2. Physical or sensory anhedonia: This refers to a diminished pleasure response to sensory stimuli, such as taste, touch, or other physical sensations. Individuals may have difficulty deriving pleasure from activities such as eating delicious food, engaging in sexual experiences, or experiencing the enjoyment of touch or warmth.
  • Treatment for anhedonia often involves a combination of psychotherapy and medication. Psychotherapeutic approaches such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and behavioral activation can help individuals identify and modify negative thought patterns and engage in pleasurable activities. Antidepressant medications, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or other classes of antidepressants, may also be prescribed to address anhedonia as part of overall symptom management.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Tangentiality is a formal thought disorder where the person responds to questions with irrelevant details that never reach a goal.

Option C. Alexithymia is difficulty in identifying and expressing emotions.

Option D. Asociality includes a lack of interest or motivation to engage in social interactions.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 37-year-old man who experienced symptoms after a sudden financial loss? He reported feeling fearful of harm, having sleep and appetite disturbances, and hearing abusive voices. These symptoms lasted for about a week. The patient has no relevant medical history, drug abuse history, or past medical history.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Brief psychotic episode

Explanation:

  • Acute psychotic disorder is characterised by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganised speech, or grossly disorganised or catatonic behaviour that lasts for < 1 month (ICD 11) or < 6 months (DSM 5).
  • DSM-5 classifies further:
    • Brief Psychotic disorder: Symptoms < 1 month
    • Schizophreniform disorder: Symptoms > 1 month- < 6 month
  • It is an acute condition that is common in the 20s to 30s, especially in women comparatively and in lower socio-economic populations.

Disorder

ICD-11 Criteria

DSM-5 Criteria

Schizoaffective Disorder
(Option D ruled out)

Symptoms of both schizophrenia and mood disorders for

≥ 1 month

Psychotic symptoms without mood disturbances for ≥ 2 weeks.

Delusional Disorder

 

Delusions present for more than three months.

Delusions are present for at least one month.

Schizophrenia

(Option A ruled out)

Two or more symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) present for ≥ one month

Two or more symptoms present for ≥ six months

Schizophrenia requires two or more symptoms, with at least one from delusions, hallucinations, thought disorder, or distortion of self-experience. Additional symptoms include negative symptoms, disorganised behaviour, or psychomotor disturbances.

Schizophreniform Disorder (Option B). According to DSM, the duration of symptoms must be more than one month but less than 6 months.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl suspects that the college principal is making a conspiracy against her and is planning to fail her in the upcoming exam. She feels that other teachers have also joined the conspiracy and students are helping them too. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Delusion of persecution

Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting with delusions of persecution, where she believes that others are conspiring against her, which is a key characteristic of this type of delusion.
  • Delusions of persecution involve the belief that one is being targeted, harmed, or harassed by others, often without any evidence.
  • In this case, the student believes that the principal, teachers, and other students are part of a conspiracy to harm her academically.

Types of delusions

Delusion

Description

Delusion of Persecution
  • Belief of being harassed, persecuted, or mistreated by others.
  • Most common type of delusion. (Option C)

Delusion of Reference
  • The belief that surrounding people are talking about them or spying on them. It is a form of delusion of persecution. (Option D ruled out)

Delusion of Grandiosity
  • Exaggerated belief in one's own importance, power, or identity.
  • Belief in being a significant figure who can help others or may claim to hear the voices of God, which reinforces their belief in their elevated status.
  • Seen in mania (as Mood-congruent delusion)

Nihilistic Delusion
  • Belief that the body/part of body/world or everything related to it has ceased to exist.
  • Also known as the delusion of negation.
  • seen in depression (most commonly) as (Mood-congruent delusion)
  • Cotard syndrome: Patient with depression having delusions of nihilism (specifically related to parts of the body).

Delusion of guilt
  • The patient firmly believes that he is a sinner, though not having committed any sin.
  • Seen in depression (as Mood-congruent delusion)

Delusion of Poverty
  • The patient is convinced that he is poor and in a state of destitution, although he is not.

Delusion of enormity
  • The patient believes that their action can produce catastrophe.
  • Eg, the patient refuses to urinate because he believes that it may flood the world.

Delusion of Infidelity
  • The belief that one's partner is unfaithful.
  • Associated factor: prolonged alcohol use
  • Also known as Othello syndrome/Morbid jealousy

De clerambault’s syndrome/ Erotomania
  • The patient (often a single woman) believes that a person of higher status is in love with her.
  • May be a feature of paranoid schizophrenia.

Hypochondriacal delusion/Delusion of ill health
  • Characteristically seen in depression, it may also be seen in schizophrenia.

Various forms of Hypochondriacal delusion:

Delusion of Infestation/ Parasitosis/ Ekbom syndrome:

  • The patient falsely believes that he is infested with insects,he does not experience sensation.
  • It affects both men and women equally and becomes more common with age.
  • ‘Empty matchbox sign’ may be present (when the patient attempts to catch the insect to show it to the clinician).

Delusional dysmorphophobia:

  • The patient believes that his body/part of his body is deformed and wants it to be corrected.

Delusional halitosis:

  • The belief that the patient has a malodorous body odour.

Incorrect Options:

Thought insertion (Option A) is a type of delusion where a person believes that someone else is forcing thoughts into their mind. The individual may feel that their thoughts are not their own and are being controlled by an external force. This symptom is commonly associated with schizophrenia but can also occur in other medical and psychiatric conditions.

Delusion of control (Option B) is characterized by the belief that an external force or agency is controlling or manipulating one's thoughts, actions, or body. The individual may feel as though they are not in control of their own behaviour and are being compelled to act against their will. This symptom is often seen in schizophrenia.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 35-year-old female patient presenting to the psychiatric outpatient department with symptoms of reduced sleep, excessive elation, and increased talkativeness lasting for one month? The patient is exhibiting disruptive behaviour by shouting at the nurses and is difficult to control. She also reports irritability and difficulty in staying focused. There is no known medical history for this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Haloperidol

Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting with symptoms of an acute manic episode, which is a feature of bipolar disorder.
  • Symptoms such as excessive elation, reduced sleep, irritability, increased talkativeness, and disruptive behaviour are characteristic of mania.
  • In this scenario, haloperidol, a typical antipsychotic, is the most appropriate treatment that works by blocking dopamine D2 receptors, which helps to control the agitation, aggression, and psychotic features associated with mania. t provides rapid symptom relief and is effective in managing acute manic episodes.

Incorrect Options:

Lithium (Option A) is a mood stabiliser primarily used for long-term management of bipolar disorder. While it is effective in preventing manic and depressive episodes, it is not suitable for acute management due to its delayed onset of action. It also requires regular serum level monitoring to avoid toxicity, making it less ideal for immediate symptom relief in this case.

Lorazepam (Option B) is a benzodiazepine used to manage anxiety and agitation but does not directly treat the underlying symptoms of mania. While it may help calm the patient temporarily, it is not effective for controlling the psychotic or manic symptoms, such as excessive energy and impulsivity, that are present in this case.

Carbamazepine (Option C) is a mood stabiliser and anticonvulsant used to treat acute manic and mixed episodes of bipolar disorder. However, its onset of action is slower compared to antipsychotics like haloperidol. It is more commonly used for long-term management and prevention rather than for rapid symptom control in acute mania, making it a less suitable option in this case.

questions.text: A doctor asked the patient what her age is and she told him that she is married to an older man, and she has 2 kids of 15 and 18 years, and she is 39 years old. What is the disorder present?
questions.solution:
The patient was asked a direct question about her age but instead provided excessive and unnecessary details about her marriage and children before eventually reaching the point. This is characteristic of circumstantial speech, where the person includes irrelevant details but eventually answers the question.

Other Options:

Derailment (Option A): This refers to the loosening of associations, where the person's speech lacks logical connection between ideas and shifts randomly to unrelated topics. In this case, the response is still somewhat related to age, making derailment unlikely.

 

Flight of Ideas (Option C): Seen in mania, this involves rapidly shifting from one topic to another, often with pressured speech and little coherence. The patient's response does not exhibit this disorganized, racing thought pattern.


Tangentiality (Option D): In this disorder, the patient never returns to the original question and goes off on unrelated tangents. However, in circumstantial speech, the person eventually answers the question, which is seen in this case.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			A. Twilight state
			
			
			1. Subnormal intelligence
			
		
		
			
			B. Oneiroid state
			
			
			2. Impaired level of consciousness
			
		
		
			
			C. Oligophrenia
			
			
			3. Persecution
			
		
		
			
			D. Paranoid ideation
			
			
			4. Oneirophrenia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Explanation:

Terms

Definition

Twilight state
  • It refers to a state of disturbed consciousness along with hallucinations.

Oneiroid state or oneirophrenia
  • Dream-like delusional derangement of consciousness in which the patient is not fully oriented in time and place.
  • A characteristic feature of this state - is the presence of kaleidoscopic quality of the dream-like experiences where reality, illusions, and hallucinations are merged into one.
  • Associated with catatonic disturbances.

Oligophrenia
  • It refers to a group of mental states characterised by subnormal levels of intellectual activity.
  • Either congenital or acquired during early infancy.
  • Associated with other cognitive disturbances, affective disorders, and volitional disorders.

Paranoid ideation
  • Refers to thinking that is dominated by persecutory, suspicious, or grandiose content.
  • Thought content is less than that for delusions.
  • Paranoid delusions refer to persecutory delusions and delusions of grandeur, control, and reference.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 43-year-old individual who arrives at the emergency department accompanied by the police, alleging that his daughter intends to harm him, but subsequent investigation by the police reveals it to be a false accusation? The patient's physical examination does not reveal any notable findings.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Delusional disorder

  • The patient's false belief that his daughter intends to harm him, despite a police investigation revealing no evidence, points to a delusional disorder.
  • It is characterised by one or more non-bizarre delusions (false beliefs about real situations) lasting for at least a month. These beliefs persist despite evidence to the contrary and are not explained by any other mental health condition.
  • Delusions are fixed false beliefs that are resistant to reason or contrary evidence and not aligned with the individual’s cultural context.

Types of delusional disorders

Type

Description

Persecutory

(Delusion of persecution)

Believing others are trying to harm them

Jealous

(Delusion of infidelity or Othello syndrome)

Believing that a lover or partner is unfaithful

Erotomanic

(Delusion of erotomania or De Clerambault’s syndrome)

Believing that another person (often of higher status) is in love with them

Somatic type

Believing he or she has some physical disorder that includes:

  • Delusion of parasitosis (infested with parasites, such as bugs or worms)
  • Delusion of dysmorphophobia (body or appearance is distorted or altered in a negative way)
  • Delusion of halitosis (bad breath)

Grandiose

(Delusion of grandeur)

Believing one has exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame

Delusion of Guilt

Believing that they are an evil person and have ruined their family

Nihilistic delusion

Deny the existence of their body, mind, loved ones, or the world, claiming they have no intelligence, that parts of their body are absent, or even believing they are dead or that the world has ended

Delusion of Poverty

Believing they are impoverished and that destitution threatens them and their family.

Mixed and unspecified type

(Delusion of misidentification)

Delusions that are a combination of types or not described by one of the categories:

  • Capgras syndrome
  • Fregoli syndrome
  • Syndrome of metamorphosis
  • Syndrome of subjective doubles

Illusion (Option B) is a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus, not a false perception without a stimulus. It occurs when a real object is perceived incorrectly, such as seeing a stick and mistaking it for a snake. is a disturbance of perception.it is the false perception of a real object.

Cotard’s syndrome (Option C), also known as nihilistic delusion, is a rare psychiatric disorder where the patient believes that they are dead or that their body or mind has ceased to exist. They may also deny the existence of others or the world around them, experiencing a distorted perception of reality.

Hallucination (Option D) is a false perception without any external stimulus. The individual perceives things that are not present, such as hearing voices or seeing images that don't exist. This is distinct from illusions, which involve real external objects.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with schizophrenia and started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushed to OPD today, complaining of upward rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Benztropine

Explanation:

  • The patient is most likely experiencing acute dystonia, a type of extrapyramidal symptom (EPS), which is a common side effect of antipsychotic medications like risperidone.
  • Upward rolling of the eyes (oculogyric crisis) is a presentation of acute dystonia, and Benztropine is the first-line treatment for acute dystonia caused by antipsychotic drugs, it is an anticholinergic medication.
  • Benztropine restores the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the brain, making it the preferred treatment for oculogyric crisis induced by risperidone.
  • Its potent antimuscarinic action, ability to counteract dopamine hyperactivity, rapid onset, and fewer sedative side effects make it more effective than alternatives like promethazine.
     

Lorazepam (Option A) is a benzodiazepine that has some muscle-relaxant properties and is used in some cases of dystonia, and IV diazepam (another benzodiazepine) can help treat oculogyric crises. However, neither lorazepam nor diazepam are considered first-line management for acute dystonia.

Olanzapine (Option C) is another atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and other disorders, and while it can be used in the management of oculogyric crises, it is not a first-line treatment.


Stop antipsychotic (Option D): This may be considered in recurrent cases of acute dystonia or if the treatment is unsuccessful (i.e., after failure of medical management with anticholinergics or antihistamines). However, immediately stopping the antipsychotic is not the first step in acute management.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a middle-aged man who visits the psychiatry OPD claiming that he has been hearing voices from aliens instructing him to harm his family members for the last seven months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Schizophrenia

The patient's presentation of auditory hallucinations (hearing voices from aliens instructing harm) persisting for seven months strongly suggests schizophrenia. Key diagnostic features include:

  • Hallucinations: Perception of voices in the absence of external stimuli, a hallmark of schizophrenia.
  • Duration: Symptoms persisting for more than six months are required for a diagnosis of schizophrenia, as per DSM-5 criteria.
  • Content of hallucinations: The bizarre and threatening nature of the auditory hallucinations aligns with the psychotic features commonly seen in schizophrenia.

Types of Schizophrenia:

Type of Schizophrenia

Characteristics

Paranoid Schizophrenia

  • Characterised by delusions and hallucinations.
  • Individuals may have a fixed belief that others are out to harm them, often leading to mistrust and vigilance.
  • Cognitive functions usually remain intact, while emotional responses may be inappropriate.

Catatonic Schizophrenia

 

Characterised by three or more of the following symptoms:

  • Motor immobility ( stupor)
  • Excessive, odd movement (stereotypies or mannerisms)
  • Waxy flexibility (bending like a wax candle)
  • Extreme negativism (resisting instructions or maintaining rigidity)
  • Unusual postures (bizarre posturing, catalepsy)
  • Echolalia or echopraxia (Mimicking speech or movements)

Disorganised (Hebephrenic) Schizophrenia
  • Involves disorganised speech and behavior.
  • Inappropriate emotional responses and poor functioning.
  • Typically associated with a poorer prognosis.

Residual Schizophrenia
  • History of schizophrenia with delusions and hallucinations (in the past 1 year) with lingering negative symptoms but minimal or no positive symptoms at present.
  • No prominent delusions or hallucinations
  • Individuals may exhibit social withdrawal and reduced emotional expression.

Simple Schizophrenia

Involves prominent negative symptoms

Undifferentiated Schizophrenia

Diagnosis for patients who do not fit into other categories presenting a mix of symptoms.

Mania (Option A) involves elevated mood, grandiosity, and hyperactivity but does not typically present with persistent hallucinations instructing harm.

Delusional Disorder (Option B) involves non-bizarre delusions without prominent hallucinations. Persistent auditory hallucinations exclude this diagnosis.

Brief Psychotic Disorder (Option D) involves psychotic symptoms lasting less than one month, ruling it out in this case where symptoms have persisted for seven months.

questions.text: Which of the following does not suggest a medical cause of mental illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Auditory hallucination

  • Auditory hallucinations are more commonly associated with psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders rather than medical causes of mental illness.
  • While medical causes (e.g., delirium and neurological disorders) can occasionally produce hallucinations, visual or tactile hallucinations are more indicative of a medical etiology than auditory hallucinations.

Elderly age (Option A): Mental illnesses in older adults are more likely to have a medical or organic cause (e.g., dementia, delirium, or metabolic abnormalities).

Loss of consciousness (Option B) suggests possible neurological issues such as epilepsy, head trauma, or other medical conditions causing altered mental states.

Acute onset (Option D): Rapid onset of psychiatric symptoms strongly suggests a medical cause, such as delirium, stroke, or infection.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was prescribed drug A after he did not respond to haloperidol and thioridazine. He now presents with excessive salivation, an increase in blood glucose, and hyperlipidemia. What is drug “A”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clozapine

Explanation:

  • Drug A is likely Clozapine, the preferred treatment for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, known to cause side effects like excessive salivation, increased blood glucose, and hyperlipidemia.

Clozapine

Class

Atypical antipsychotic (1st atypical antipsychotic discovered)

Mechanism of action

Primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C), which helps reduce symptoms in treatment-resistant cases.

Uses

  • DOC for TRS (Treatment-resistant schizophrenia): Used only when a patient doesn't respond to at least 2 antipsychotics.
  • Only antipsychotics with anti-suicidal properties (shown ↓ suicidal ideas in Schizophrenia patients).

Side effects

Severe risks (Pneumonic: SAM):

  • S - Seizures
    • Dose dependant
    • > 600 mg has more seizures
  • A - Agranulocytosis
    • Idiosyncratic
    • ↓ WBC (Neutrophils)
    • The main reason for deaths and withdrawal from the market
    • Weekly monitoring of WBC and Neutrophil count for 1st 6 months is important
  • M - Myocarditis
    • Idiosyncratic
    • Chest pain
    • Dyspnea
    • Abnormal ECG

Common side effects:

  • Sedation (most common)
  • Weight gain (maximum weight gain of all antipsychotics)
  • Hypersalivation (sialorrhea)
  • Sedation
  • Tachycardia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Constipation
  • Hypotension

Rare side effects include myocarditis.

Contraindications

  • WBC count - < 3500/mm
  • Previous bone marrow disorder
  • H/o of Agranulocytosis during Clozapine treatment
  • Use of another bone marrow suppressant (carbamazepine)

Monitoring

TLC and ANC

  • Once a week for the first 6 months
  • Once in two weeks for the next 6 months
  • Once a month till the patient continues

Incorrect Options:

Ziprasidone (Option A) is an atypical antipsychotic medication that is less likely to cause the mentioned side effects.

Risperidone (Option B) is another atypical antipsychotic, and while it can cause some metabolic side effects, it is not typically associated with hypersalivation.

Aripiprazole (Option D) is also an atypical antipsychotic, but hypersalivation is not a typical side effect of this medication

questions.text: All of the following are features of pseudohallucinations, except?

choices.text: They are perceived in the outer objective space

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- They are perceived in the outer objective space:

  • This statement is incorrect. Pseudohallucinations are not perceived in the objective space. They are typically perceived in the subjective or internal space of the individual's mind. These perceptions might seem real to the person experiencing them, but they are not projected into the external environment.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- They occur without external stimulus: Pseudohallucinations are defined as perceptions that occur without an external stimulus. In other words, the individual experiences sensory perceptions that seem real but are not triggered by any actual external input. This can be contrasted with true hallucinations, which are perceptions without external stimuli but are experienced as if they are real.

Option C- They are not vivid: hallucinations are often described as vivid and intense sensory experiences. While they are not based on external stimuli, they can still be very detailed and realistic to the person experiencing them. This vividness contributes to the confusion between pseudohallucinations and true hallucinations.

Option D- They are done voluntarily: Pseudohallucinations, like true hallucinations, are  under the control of the individual experiencing them. They occur voluntarily and are often distressing to the person. The lack of control distinguishes hallucinations from imagination or deliberate thought processes.

questions.text: A boy is experiencing low mood, decreased energy and decreased interest in his surroundings. He has not been taking food for the past one week. The thought sample says - ‘I lost my head. I am dead. How can I eat?’. What type of delusion does the patient exhibit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Nihilistic delusion

  • The given scenario, where the patient believes his head is missing and that he is dead, is diagnosed as a Nihilistic delusion (also known as Cotard's delusion or the delusion of negation).
  • It is a psychiatric condition where the individual believes they are dead, nonexistent, or that parts of their body are missing or decaying, often involving denial of their body, mind, loved ones, and the world.

Types of delusional disorders:

Type

Description

Persecutory (Delusion of persecution)

Believing others are trying to harm them

Jealous (Delusion of infidelity or Othello syndrome)

Believing that a lover or partner is unfaithful

Erotomanic  (Delusion of erotomania or De Clerambault’s syndrome)

Believing that another person (often of higher status) is in love with them

Somatic type

Believing he or she has some physical disorder that includes:

  • Delusion of parasitosis (infested with parasites, such as bugs or worms)
  • Delusion of dysmorphophobia (body or appearance is distorted or altered in a negative way)
  • Delusion of halitosis (bad breath)

Grandiose  (Delusion of grandeur)

Believing one has exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame

Delusion of Guilt

Believing that they are an evil person and have ruined their family

Nihilistic delusion (Option B)

Deny the existence of their body, mind, loved ones, or the world, claiming they have no intelligence, that parts of their body are absent, or even believing they are dead or that the world has ended

Delusion of Poverty

Believing they are impoverished and that destitution threatens them and their family.

Mixed and unspecified type (Delusion of misidentification)

(Option A ruled out)

Delusions that are a combination of types or not described by one of the categories:

  • Capgras syndrome
  • Fregoli syndrome
  • Syndrome of metamorphosis
  • Syndrome of subjective doubles

Bizarre delusions (Option C) are characterised by beliefs that are clearly implausible and not derived from ordinary life experiences.

Hypochondriacal delusion (Option D) involves the belief of having a severe illness or disease despite evidence to the contrary. The patient's statement does not directly reflect a preoccupation with physical illness or disease, so this option is not applicable.

Cerebral bleeding (Option D), or intracerebral hemorrhage, is not a recognised or common side effect of clozapine. questions.text: Patient, who is on antipsychotic medication for his schizophrenia, started to have dystonia. Management of this patient is by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Benzhexol

Explanation:

  • Anticholinergic medications like benzhexol (which acts on the parasympathetic nervous system by inhibiting efferent pulses directly) can be used to treat Acute Dystonia.
  • It refers to brief, sudden muscle contractions that lead to abnormal movements or postures.
  • This extrapyramidal side effect, commonly seen with antipsychotic medications, occurs when there is a disruption in the nigrostriatal pathway, which plays a key role in motor control.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Oculogyric crises (upward rolling of eyes)
    • Tongue protrusion
    • Trismus (jaw muscles)
    • Torticollis (neck muscles twisting to one side)
    • Laryngospasm
    • Dysarthria, Dysphasia (glossopharyngeal symptoms)
    • Dystonic postures of the limbs and trunk.
  • Management:
    • Anticholinergic drugs:
      • Parenteral (IV or IM) is for immediate treatment
      • Oral is used for prophylaxis
      • Drugs include Benztropine, Diphenhydramine, and Promethazine.

 

Replace with fluphenazine (Option B): Fluphenazine is a first-generation antipsychotic primarily used to treat symptoms of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders.

Increase the dose of haloperidol (Option C): Haloperidol is a first-generation antipsychotic (typical antipsychotic) effective for managing psychosis but is known for a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as dystonia, akathisia, and tardive dyskinesia.

Clozapine (Option D) is a second-generation antipsychotic specifically indicated for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is known for its efficacy in patients who do not respond to other antipsychotic medications. It can lead to a rare adverse effect, such as granulocytosis.

questions.text: Atypical antipsychotic with the least metabolic side effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ziprasidone

Explanation:

  • Among the given options, Ziprasidone has the least metabolic side effects, with minimal impact outside the CNS, no significant weight gain, and no sustained prolactin elevation.

 

Ziprasidone

Class

Atypical antipsychotic / 2nd generation antipsychotics

Mechanism of action

D2 and 5HT2A receptor antagonists

Uses

  • Schizophrenia
  • Bipolar I disorder
    • Acute treatment: Monotherapy of manic or mixed episodes
    • Maintenance treatment: Adjunct to lithium or valproate.

Adverse effects

  • Most common side effects are somnolence, headache, dizziness, nausea, and lightheadedness.
  • Prolongation of the QTc complex
  • Less extrapyramidal side effects, hyperprolactinemia and more metabolic side effects.

 

Haloperidol (Option A) is a first-generation antipsychotic (typical antipsychotic) effective for managing psychosis but is known for a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as dystonia, akathisia, and tardive dyskinesia.

Risperidone (Option B) is an atypical antipsychotic known for causing more extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia, as well as an increased stroke risk. It is used to treat schizophrenia, autism, acute mania, and bipolar disorder. It has more metabolic side effects than ziprasidone.

Quetiapine (Option D) is an atypical antipsychotic approved for schizophrenia, unipolar depression, acute mania, and bipolar disorder. Its adverse effects include somnolence, headache, dizziness, constipation, weight gain, and elevated plasma triglycerides and cholesterol.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a patient who believes their bodily sensations or movements are controlled or influenced by an external agency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Somatic passivity

Explanation:

  • Somatic Passivity (also known as Thought Alienation or Passivity Phenomenon) is the diagnosis of a patient who believes their bodily sensations or movements are controlled or influenced by an external agency. It is one of the hallmark symptoms of Schizophrenia.

 

Schizophrenia’s First Rank Symptoms:

Category

Symptom

Description

Thought Alienation Phenomenon

Thought Insertion

A belief that others are placing thoughts into the patient’s mind.

Thought Withdrawal

A belief that thoughts are being removed from the patient’s mind.

Thought Broadcasting

A belief that others can know or access the patient’s thoughts.

Made Phenomenon

Made Volition

A belief that actions are controlled by an external force.

Made Affect

A belief that external forces are altering the patient's emotions.

Made Impulses

Sudden urges or impulses that are perceived as implanted by others.

Auditory Hallucinations

Voices Arguing/Discussing

The patient hears voices discussing or arguing about them, often in the third person.

Example: The patient hears two voices arguing, one saying, “He’s a failure,” and the other replying, “No, he’s not.”

Voices Commenting

The patient hears a voice providing commentary on their actions, usually in the third person.

Example: While cooking, a patient hears a voice say, “She’s burning the food,” reflecting their actions.

Audible Thoughts

The patient hears their own thoughts spoken aloud by a voice.

Example: A patient thinks, “I need to go to the store,” and immediately hears a voice say the same phrase.

Somatic Passivity

Physical sensations are perceived as imposed by external agents.

Example: A patient feels a burning sensation in their arm and believes it is caused by invisible rays from a satellite.

Delusional Perception

A normal perception is interpreted with a delusional belief

Example: A patient sees a red car parked outside and believes it indicates the police are monitoring them for criminal activity.

 

Delusion of nihilism (Option A) refers to the delusion where an individual denies the existence of their body, mind, loved ones, or the world, claiming they have no intelligence, that parts of their body are absent, or even believing they are dead or that the world has ended. It is seen in disorders such as schizophrenia and depression.

Delusion of reference (Option B) is a condition in which the patient believes that someone is talking about him or spying on him.

Othello syndrome (Option C) or Delusion of infidelity/ jealousy refers to a condition in which the patient believes that the partner or spouse is having an affair even though that is not true. Prolonged alcohol use is linked to this condition.

questions.text: A patient shows flat affect. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
Flat affect refers to a lack of emotional expression, where the patient shows little or no facial expressions, gestures, or vocal tone variations despite the context. This is classified as a negative symptom in psychiatric disorders, especially schizophrenia. Negative symptoms represent a loss or reduction of normal functions, such as diminished emotional expression, social withdrawal, and lack of motivation.

 

Types:

  1. Positive Symptoms (Option A): These reflect exaggerations or distortions of normal functions.
  • Delusions: False beliefs not based in reality, e.g., persecutory or grandiose delusions.
  • Hallucinations: Perceptions without external stimuli, typically auditory (e.g., hearing voices).
  • Disorganised speech: Incoherent or illogical speech, such as loose associations or "word salad."
  • Disorganised behaviour: Erratic or inappropriate actions, including agitation or inappropriate affect.

​​​​​​​2. Negative Symptoms: These involve loss or reduction of normal functions.

  • Avolition: Lack of motivation to perform goal-directed activities, such as self-care.
  • Anhedonia: Inability to experience pleasure from activities which were previously preasurable.
  • Alogia: Poverty of speech, brief or uninformative responses.
  • Flat affect or Blunting actions (Option B): Reduced emotional expression, monotone speech, or lack of facial expressions.
  • Social withdrawal: Lack of interest in social relationships.

3.Cognitive Symptoms (Option D): These affect thinking and memory and have a moderate prognosis.

  • Impaired attention: Difficulty focusing or sustaining attention.
  • Impaired working memory: Trouble holding and manipulating information.
  • Executive dysfunction: Difficulty with planning, organising, and problem-solving.
  • Slowed processing speed: Slower response to information and tasks.


 

Other Options:


Affect symptom (Option C): While flat affect is related to emotional expression, "affect symptom" is not a standard classification in psychiatric terminology. Instead, it falls under negative symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with schizophrenia had been compliant with her prescribed olanzapine for several months. However, she discontinued the treatment. Which of the following is the most likely reason for her discontinuation?
questions.solution:
Olanzapine, an atypical antipsychotic, is commonly associated with significant weight gain and metabolic side effects. Many patients discontinue the medication due to excessive weight gain, increased appetite, and risk of metabolic syndrome (including diabetes and dyslipidemia). This is one of the most frequent reasons for non-compliance with olanzapine treatment.

 

  • Antipsychotic Medications:

 

First Generation Antipsychotics

(Typical)

Second Generation Antipsychotics

(Atypical)

Second Generation Antipsychotics

(Atypical)

D2 receptor antagonist

Partial D2 Agonists

D2/5-HT2A Antagonists
  • Haloperidol
  • Fluphenazine
  • Perphenazine
  • Chlorpromazine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Brexpiprazole
  • Cariprazine
  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone
  • Lurasidone
  • Clozapine
  • Treatment Duration:
    • For first-episode patients, a minimum of 1-2 years of treatment is recommended.
    • For those with multiple episodes, indefinite treatment is often advised.
  • Side Effects:

Extrapyramidal Side Effects (EPS)
  • Common with first-generation antipsychotics, including symptoms like
    • Acute dystonia - Earliest, can occur within minutes of the injection (Option B)
    • Parkinson's - Occurs within days to weeks
    • Akathisia - Occurs within days to weeks (Option C)
  • Alternatives for management include dose reduction, antiparkinson medications, or switching to medications with lower EPS risk.

Tardive Dyskinesia (TD)

 

(Option D)
  • Affects 20-30% of patients on long-term first-generation antipsychotics, with higher risk in the elderly and those with cognitive or mood disorders.
  • Prevention strategies include using the lowest effective doses and switching to other medications like Clozapine.

Sedation & Postural hypotension

Especially with low-potency antipsychotics.

Long-term antipsychotic use can elevate prolactin levels, affecting sexual function and potentially leading to osteoporosis.

questions.text: A young male who is shy and prefers social isolation appears to be emotionally cold and resides alone. There is no history of hallucinations or delusions. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Schizoid personality disorder:

  • Schizoid personality disorder: Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a pattern of social detachment and emotional coldness. Individuals with this disorder typically have limited interest in social relationships, prefer solitary activities, and often appear emotionally distant. They tend to avoid close relationships and may show a lack of desire for social interaction. The description of a young male who is shy, prefers social isolation, and appears emotionally cold aligns more closely with the features of schizoid personality disorder.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Paranoid personality disorder: Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others, interpreting their motives as malevolent. Individuals with paranoid personality disorder often exhibit a pattern of suspicion, hyper-vigilance, and a reluctance to confide in others.

Option C - Antisocial personality disorder: Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a disregard for the rights of others and a lack of empathy. Individuals with this disorder often engage in impulsive and irresponsible behavior, have difficulties conforming to social norms, and may exhibit a pattern of deceit and manipulation.

Option D - Emotionally unstable personality disorder: Emotionally unstable personality disorder, also known as borderline personality disorder, is characterized by a pervasive pattern of instability in mood, self-image, and interpersonal relationships. Individuals with this disorder often experience intense and rapidly shifting emotions, engage in impulsive behavior, and have difficulties maintaining stable relationships.
